--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "John Arrowwood" <jarrowwx@h...> wrote:
> >From: Mitchell Timin <zenguyuno@y...>
> >
> >Ken wrote:
> >
> > > By the way, performance gains in crossover will have
> > > almost no
> > > effect on performance in general, so it's not really
> > > worth too much
> > > effort trying to optimize crossover.  In every
> > > experiment I've seen
> > > except the very simplest, NEAT takes up a tiny
> > > fraction of
> > > computation time.  It's the evaluations that are
> > > expensive.
> >
> >Each evaluation requires the operation (or
> >computation) of the neural net itself, i.e., giving it
> >some inputs, and progagating the signals through the
> >network.  When you studied the time required for
> >evaluation did you separate it into time for
> >problem-specific code vs. neural net computation code?
> >  For a complex network with many connections that
> >might be substantial.
> 
> How would that distinction be helpful?  Are you thinking that 
there might be 
> ways of optimizing the network computation step?  And you want to 
know 
> whether the effort is worthwhile?  For some domains, it would be...
> 

I'm also not totally sure what Mitchell is getting at with this 
distinction, but what I can say is that it depends a lot on the 
problem domain.  If you are doing realistic physical simulations, 
most likely the neural network activation is a negligable expense 
compared to the simulation itself.  On the other hand if you are 
doing something that only takes one or two activations to complete 
an evaluation on preprocessed inputs, like XOR, then the activation 
is most of the expense.  

ken
